citations.narrative:
Buildings 35 and 37 have sections of enclosures where paint is actively flaking off metal support beams above
enclosures, and at the base frame of the door where the dogs are scratching. Flaking paint was also observed on the
ground underneath enclosures. Flaking paint can pose a potential hazard to the dogs and the enclosures in these building
need to be maintained in good repair for the safety of the animals.
Correct by: June 30, 2023

During the inspection a single ferret was found in a designated empty enclosure after the remaining members of the group
had been moved. It’s the facility’s husbandry practice to move groups of animals from one set of enclosures to another
when its time to sanitize buildings. In this instance, three of the four animals were moved with one left in the enclosure.
The ferret was found in the nesting box of the open pen, with food and water available. Employees must make sure that
the number of animals pulled for enclosure transfer match the number of animals identified per the facility’s handling and
husbandry practices. Employees must be adequately trained under the direction of a supervisor to maintain professionally
acceptable levels of husbandry care for these animals.
Correct by: June 22, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Attending Veterinarian and additional facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
EILIS KARR, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
KERI LUPO, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
PAULA GLADUE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

Buildings 35 and 37 have sections of enclosures where paint is actively flaking off metal support beams above

3.132 
   
Employees. 
During the inspection a single ferret was found in a designated empty enclosure after the remaining members of the group 
had been moved. It’s the facility’s husbandry practice to move groups of animals from one set of enclosures to another 
when its time to sanitize buildings. In this instance, three of the four animals were moved with one left in the enclosure. 
The ferret was found in the nesting box of the open pen, with food and water available. Employees must make sure that 
the number of animals pulled for enclosure transfer match the number of animals identified per the facility’s handling and 
husbandry practices. Employees must be adequately trained under the direction of a supervisor to maintain professionally 
acceptable levels of husbandry care for these animals.
